It provides an incentive for the local community to band together where there are no jobs. The cost of CDEP is an extra 30 per cent on top of unemployment benefits. So they work for less than the dole, but funding allows for infrastructure development.

In this budget, the government has frozen the expansion of CDEP, the work for the dole program. Instead of allowing for the extra 2,500 places in CDEP, the government has allocated the money for unemployment benefits. It is madness. It is an absurdity. It seems to me that the attitude of this government is to say, `If the Labor Party was involved in it, then we need to change it because it can't be any good.'
What is the history of CDEP? ATSIC outlines the history in the attachment to its press release, and it is worth reading. On the bottom of page 5 of the attachment it says:

The Community Development Employment Scheme was introduced on a pilot basis for remote Aboriginal communities by the Fraser Government in 1977 in response to those communities concerned that large scale payments of unemployment benefits would be both unproductive and cause considerable social problems. It has evolved into a scheme in which over 27,000 indigenous Australians voluntarily forgo their rights to Job Search Allowance (JSA) or New Start Allowance (NSA) to participate as employees in 262 CDEP projects throughout Australia for a wage that is approximately equivalent to JSA or NSA entitlements.

More than 25% of working age indigenous Australians participate in the scheme and more than 60% of new jobs for indigenous Australians between 1991 and 1994 were created through expansion of CDEP. During the same period the CDEP scheme was responsible for the creation of 5,500 of the total 8,000 new jobs for Indigenous Australians.
The scheme benefits

. Communities by generating a sense of pride in ownership and control and helps address a wide range of social issues such as long term unemployment, dislocation from mainstream labour market programs, substance abuse and habitual offending.
. Individuals by providing a transition to work, access to flexible training programs, helps to establish self esteem and a sense of cultural identity.

. Governments by providing for municipal services, particularly in remote communities, where local government is unable or unwilling to provide services and is critical to other service providers in the delivery of services to remote communities at outstations.

The impact of not proceeding with the planned expansion will be felt both in the short term and the long term in respect of all the benefits identified above. More especially the cuts come at a time when the indigenous labour force is growing at 8,000 per annum. The likely impact is that indigenous unemployment will increase sharply as a result of this measure over the next four years.

They then go on to talk about recent studies. And that is the great tragedy and the great irony. We are told that this government is going to concentrate on health, on unemployment and on housing. This is integral and it is related to those concerns, especially in regional Australia.

Studies by Professor Colin Tatz from Macquarie University show that if you take away infrastructure spending or if you do not have community or cultural activities in remote Aboriginal communities, then those communities have an increase in youth suicide; they have an increase in delinquency; they have an increase in alcohol related problems; and they have an increase in health related problems.

What worries me is that seven months into a new government we have a government apportioning blame, not a government coming down with a considered program, not a government coming down in this sensitive area with policies that have any long‐term benefits. This was a program that was created by the Fraser government. We acknowledged, when we were in government, the benefits of the program and we expanded it. In the mainstream community's view it is work for the dole. And, what have we got? The government is discarding the expansion of the program and just allocating the money for people to receive unemployment benefits. That is not helping anyone.

It is a problem in a number of other areas as well. The tragedy is that not a lot of people are listening. There is anxiety in the community; there has been so much change that people are concerned, and they are looking for the simple solutions—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 8.13 to 8.38 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the division, it is worth quoting again from the ATSIC press release of 16 August 1996 as to what the ATSIC board had to do when, in effect, the minister announced these cuts and then said it was up to the ATSIC board to determine where the cuts would occur. I said at the time that what the minister was doing was handing the ATSIC board a poisoned chalice because there were already criticisms of ATSIC from within. To then turn around and say to the organisation, `We are going to impose $470 million worth of cuts but you are going to pick where these cuts are going,' is the wrong principle.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister might argue that this is in accordance with the principles of self‐determination. What should have happened was that the ATSIC board should have been consulted on where the cuts were to be made. There should have been recommendations but the minister should have worn the responsibility for where the cuts would take place. Instead, what he has done is leave the ATSIC board open to criticism from within the community.
These are the other measures mentioned in the press release following the government's announcement. It said:
. . . the ATSIC board had reluctantly concluded it was forced to terminate the following:
. the Community Training program, which means that ATSIC will have no labour market program other than CDEP;
. the development of Industry Strategies, which had been an initiative of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody;
. the Movement to Award Wages program, which means that ATSIC will no longer be able to supplement those organisations moving their indigenous staff to award wages; and

. the Community and Youth Support program, which will effectively remove from ATSIC responsibility for assisting indigenous organisations providing community and social services to Aboriginal people. It is now the total responsibility of Commonwealth and State agencies to provide needed community services and welfare to indigenous people.

There is something else that needs to be said. ATSIC has only been in existence for a couple of years, since the early 1990s. There is a perception that ATSIC provides all the services to the indigenous community. It does not; it only provides part of the services. The red tape and the accountability that ATSIC has to observe are just double standards compared to what we ask of the rest of the community. The guilty parties in terms of the lack of services going to the indigenous community are state and territory governments. Where is the accountability for those governments in terms of providing essential services that we, the rest of the community, take for granted? We only allowed ATSIC to administer health services for a four‐year period. We took them away from it in the end after consultation with the ATSIC board and the services were picked up by the Department of Health.

BREAK.PARA: There needs to be a coordinated whole of government approach to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander problem in this country. It is not only the nation's eyes that are watching John Howard as Prime Minister, it is going to be the world's eyes, given that we are hosting the Sydney Olympics in the year 2000. Like it or not, there is a concern in the broader community. It might be popular in the short term to pick these soft targets that the opinion pollsters tell you, `That is going to go down well with those battlers who switched their vote on 2 March,' but over time the government is going to run out of alibis. They have had seven months.

I remember the press conference that was held by the Prime Minister after the first cabinet meeting with the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. We were told about the expose on the Sunday program. All this time on, there has not been shown to be any substance in those allegations—allegations that were actually pursued by the ATSIC office of evaluation and audit itself. There has been no evidence of widespread corruption, but evidence of problems in terms of some areas of administration in answering letters; technical breaches, as they are called.

We had a situation where the ATSIC organisation has been forced to pay $1.4 million to meet the cost of a special auditor. That was part of the first cabinet decision. A couple of weeks ago that decision to impose a special auditor on ATSIC and those organisations was struck down as illegal. The minister was acting outside the powers given to him under the ATSIC Act—a 3‐0 decision by the Federal Court. Yet ATSIC was still required to pay the $1.4 million for that special audit, that illegal audit.

The Labor Party has no problems with accountability. We have no problems with the proper accounting of public funds. The situation is that the way this government is going, in this area and a number of other areas, is all opinion poll driven. It is telling people what they want to hear. It is portraying, with the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), this false prophet, that things are simple, that they have simple solutions. They are not and they do not. They are complicated.

We live in a humane and compassionate society. Australia is a fairer society than the United States was under Reagan and under Bush. It is a fairer society than Great Britain was under Thatcher. We do not want to go down the Thatcher path, down the Reagan path. As conservatives are getting turned out of office around the rest of the world, we took a different course. It will not take the Australian electorate long to wake up. There are no simple solutions, and in this area what is required is empathy and sensitivity.

I have said time and time again since I have been a shadow minister that the Labor Party is prepared to play a constructive role with the government. We acknowledge that there is a new government in town, but we do not accept the way it is going in this area. It is a government without compassion. It is a government that does not have the solutions and it is a government that should take heed. It should count to 10 and pull back a little bit. It has been knocked over in the courts already and I think it will not withstand scrutiny. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —One always listens to the learned and gallant member for Banks (Mr Melham) with concern and interest, and also in appreciation of his sincerity in matters of this nature. But, I must remind him, since he mentioned Professor Colin Tatz, that it was Professor Tatz—was it not?—who made a visit to Aboriginal communities in 1971, I think, and found them in an absolutely deplorable situation. About 20 years later he made another visit to those communities and found an even worse situation. That is something that cannot be ignored in looking at these sensitive issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The policies over those 20 years involved, in many cases, doling out money without looking for achievable goals and without determining that what we need is outcomes—not just spending and telling people to take the money and go away. We really have to look at the history, certainly of the government that he was part of—a member of the backbench, I think, at that stage—during that 13 years, and, in particular, we also have to look at the overall history of Aboriginal spending.

To say that we have to look at it is not to say that we have any predisposed ill view towards Aborigines. It is an absolute outrage and an insult to suggest that we, on this side of the House, do not have compassion and caring towards that very disadvantaged sector of the community. But, in so far as ATSIC is concerned, any organisation that spends $140 million of its something like $800 million budget on administering itself, in an area where money is as scarce as it is in this area, has to be looked at carefully and there has to be a thorough examination of whether or not that sort of money can be spent in really uplifting the lives of Aborigines on the ground. In that respect, and in principle, I support money going in at the bottom and not money going in at the top. That is all I wish to say in relation to some of those remarks by my honourable friend.

The budget, in my view, has been accepted widely in the community as a good budget. It is a budget that has had to take hard decisions, but it also is a budget of forward thinking in relation to some particular areas of interest that I have, notably the training initiatives and the focus on moving towards the expansion of vocational education in schools, and, in particular, the recognition of the need for greater apprenticeship and traineeship opportunities. It is interesting to note that $187 million is going to be developed.

In my own electorate of Dickson, the Pine Rivers High School has already, to some extent, been a beneficiary of the new focus towards developing, enhancing and expanding this latent opportunity. When a school like Pine Rivers has expensive machinery sitting idle between the hours of 3.00 p.m., after school finishes, and a reasonable hour for training, something like 10.00 p.m., and on holidays and weekends, and we have people out there who need training, it is absolutely incumbent upon us to try to utilise that equipment after hours. We must use it, as well, obviously, in relation to training in schools. The after hours use, which is part of the program that Minister David Kemp mentioned in parliament recently, is going to be taken advantage of in this particular area, and I applaud the direction of the government in that area.

It is also important to realise that difficult decisions had to be taken in the overall budget context. The expenditure side of the equation had to be carefully looked at. However, in doing so, we must not be too blinded in looking for the black figure. There are groups of people out there—and I know this from representations that have been made to me in my electorate—who are largely being forgotten.

These people have worked for something like 30 years in the Australian Public Service or perhaps in industry. They have suddenly found themselves out of work due to rationalisation or changes to industry structures—or whatever fancy terms are applied. One cannot help but be extraordinarily moved when confronted by these people who are the victims of the new age of rationalisation and reorganisation of companies, government departments and so forth.

These people have intrinsic worth and intrinsic value. They have great skills and great wisdom. It is absolutely shocking that people have reached an age where they have so much to contribute, have learnt such a lot, and yet suddenly find themselves victims. This has not just occurred recently. Indeed, one particular example goes back something like 18 months, but the process is unfortunately coming to fruition for this particular constituent fairly soon.

Over a period of time he has been, as it were, wound down and shunted into a particular area. It is a bit like what happens to old rolling stock. They are gradually shunted around on the train tracks and then put into a shed and left there, forgotten. However, these people are not forgotten by me. In this time of budgetary restraint we must not forget that there is a human factor involved. We must not forget the people who have these skills and this wisdom. Just because they are in their mid or late 40s and sometimes 50s does not mean they should be on the scrap heap. I do not accept that at all. We must always come back to the human factor.

In that respect, I also have a criticism of those who are in work and their concern for those who are not in work. For a number of years, former Labor minister Clyde Cameron heavily criticised the 17.5 per cent loading on annual leave. He pointed out that it was intended for shift workers who received particular allowances which were built into the nature of their work. When they went on holidays, this allowance was designed to assist them to have a reasonable annual leave. That allowance then drifted right across the economy, and I recall Clyde Cameron speaking about the fat cats who got it as well.

Both during the election campaign and since, a number of working people have said to me that they do not really need this. I question the notion that that is a non‐negotiable, bottom line condition that could never be negotiated away in relation to what we are looking at in terms of rationalising workplace agreements and so forth. In this day and age, when people are out of work to such a degree, can we afford to have that luxury when, apart from the hardliners, most people would not really insist on having that loading? And yet now it is being built into the structure. I question that.

I really wonder whether we should be starting to look at that, because it is obvious for all of us to see that there is a disparity between those who are in work and those who are not in work. Those who are not working are trudging around looking for work and those who are in work are doing very well, thanks very much. Some would say, and I would say, that in some cases they are doing too well at the expense of those who are not in work. It is easy to be critical of the trade unions' position on this, and I am sure the honourable member opposite will not accept this point of view. Once a member is out of work they generally cease to be a member of a union and as far as the union is concerned it is not terribly interested in him or her once they lose their job. I think that culture is to be deprecated, that once they are out of work the union is not particularly interested in that person.

I also wanted to mention another area that concerns me about the budget, and that is the area of foreign aid. I believe that it is unfortunate that the ratio of aid to GNP has now dropped from 0.34 per cent to 0.29 per cent—the lowest percentage that we have ever contributed to foreign aid. Unfortunately, we have a populist view that has recently gained currency, where we have a member of parliament saying there should not be any foreign aid. I have had people say that to me in the course of my travels in the electorate, but I ask them, `Can you imagine your children with no basic services, lucky to have a crust of bread in their mouths every day, with no sanitation and no roof over their heads? Can you imagine that situation in your own children's case? Can you then say we should not have foreign aid?' They always come back to reality when you put that scenario to them.

BREAK.PARA: Unfortunately, we have this populist line that we would be a lot better off as far as our country is concerned if we did not have foreign aid. With a little bit of thinking about it, you come back to reality. It can be put this way: Australians have a history of helping their neighbours. That is part of the Australian ethos—to help your neighbour. Who is your neighbour? Is it just the bloke next door or the widow down the street? Is it someone in the other suburb? Or is it the neighbourhood of the whole community, and that is the world community, not just the community beside you.

To suggest that your neighbour is only that person living very handy to you is, in my view, to have a very narrow mind on this issue. I hate the use of the word `racist' because it is bandied about so easily. If a person has a different view to you then they are a racist. But when you think about it, to actually say, `Let us look after our own backyard and not worry about them,' isn't that really discriminating on the basis of race? Isn't that the purest form of discrimination on the basis of race? That means saying that our near neighbours are the ones we should look after and those others are not really our neighbours. Why? Because they are not living close, they have a different colour skin or their eyes are differently shaped to ours.

I think we have a duty to the world community to look after those who are in dire need. The figures show that 20 per cent of people have 85 per cent of the world income and the poorest 20 per cent of those have only 1.4 per cent of the world's income. When you look at the statistics, how can a cut in the aid budget be justified? I do not cavil at the idea of trying to ensure that aid is better distributed and more wisely directed, but those who espouse that populist view of cutting out aid should question whether in the long run we are not going to be worse off. Aren't we going to be seen in the eyes of the world to be a miserable and selfish country? At the same time, by denying people the assistance that they need, we are perpetuating and entrenching more strongly the gulf between rich and poor.

I emphasise in particular the wise use of aid, that is, the provision of the pump to pump out the water, or the provision of seed. The development of the infrastructure within the communities is going to help them in the end to improve their position. That is really what it is about. It is not about just throwing money at the situation, it is about providing solutions, providing education. There is a welcome increase in the aid budget for basic education and primary health care. In that respect I support the government's approach because education is one factor that is very important in ameliorating this problem.

On the other side of the coin, the marginal decrease in funds for Africa and the decrease for south Asia is very disturbing. It is something that we cannot ignore. It is something that we have a duty to do something about. It is a duty of common humanity what we are talking about here. It does not do us any good to put it in the language that was put in the budget papers of, `Well, we really have to solve our own problems first'. That is an appeal to the most basic instincts. One could accept the cut without comment but to have a cut with that sort of self‐justification is unacceptable and I do not agree with that sort of approach. In my view, the overall cut is a very sad one in the circumstances and it is a sad comment on our society.

Overall, the budget is about correcting endemic debt problems at the national level, and that is to be applauded. Those hard decisions have had to be taken. In the long run one can say that Australia will be better off because of those decisions. The budget sets a path for recovery. However, there are areas of concern that we must never lose sight of and they include the human element, the unemployment element, and the aid element that I have just mentioned.

In addition, as mentioned by the member for Banks (Mr Melham), we have to be very careful in relation to the area of Aboriginal welfare. We must ensure that money spent there is well directed money and not wasted money, but we must ensure at the same time that we assist those who are in the least advantaged position in the community.
In general, I welcome the thrust of the budget but with the reservations that I have mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate following on from my colleague, the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith), at a point where he referred to assistance for Aboriginal people. As a former Labor minister for Aboriginal Affairs and as one who held a portfolio for six years I want to say that I was deeply distressed and concerned by the statements made by the present Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) who, although he described the taking of Aboriginal children away from their parents as horrible, went on to say that some Aboriginal children had benefited by that experience.

SPEECH.PARA: That was a dark period in Australian history. I have no doubt that for those who administered it they thought that what they were doing was the right thing. However, I have never met an Aboriginal person, no matter their age, who had been separated from their parents who did not at the first conceivable opportunity go in search of them—and found them too in many cases.

What they often found was a family that was completely dysfunctional, which is not surprising given that three or four children had been taken away from their family in their early years and transported miles away from their relatives. The Aboriginal people have a strong extended family concept and there is a great feeling of loyalty to each other within that. The pain and the suffering that was inflicted upon the parents—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 9.05 to 9.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time of the bells ringing, I was expressing my concern about the statements made by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. When he was appointed I said that he needed time; he needed time to get over the complexities of what is probably one of the most difficult portfolios in government. The statement that he made has led to a continued loss of confidence and loss of respect for the minister; that statement will come back to haunt him. He should modify and retract those statements because there are people living in the Aboriginal society whose lives are still, irrespective of whatever education they may have had, dysfunctional. They will never overcome the pain and the burden of those actions of separating them from their families. This was an inappropriate statement and it is a matter, I hope, that the minister will, either immediately, or in time, correct.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that, because of some of the aspects of government policy, Aboriginal leadership across Australia is increasingly losing confidence in the government. We are heading down a track where we could easily see massive confrontation, with Aboriginal people believing that there is no hope for them, and no hope for their future in this society so long as the government continues with its present policy. That is a situation which would adversely affect all of us.

BREAK.PARA: The other aspect that I want to touch on very quickly is some of the remarks that were made by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) in her maiden speech. It has taken this nation, under a variety of governments, some time to get to the point where one can honestly say that there is no element of racism involved in our immigration policy. Wherever you come from—it does not matter whether you are seeking family reunion, whether you are trying to come here as a skilled person, or how you are trying to enter—the tests are exactly the same.

I have to take issue with the honourable member for Oxley, certainly at a very personal level, because of the quote that she made of the late honourable Arthur Calwell, the founder of our immigration policy. She took—as it was possible to take, given his time in politics—a sentence to claim some support and express some admiration for an attitude which he expressed as minister at a time when he had just come out of a war in which many Australians had died and many families were suffering as a result of the near Japanese invasion of Australia.

Calwell was well aware of the prevailing sentiment in Australia, as was the then leader of the Liberal Party, Robert Gordon Menzies. There was a generational attitude. In my own party—and I was present at the conference that overturned the white Australia policy—one could accurately predict the vote on the ages of the delegates. I do not think it was much different in the Liberal Party. And the fact is that we have come a long way since people were excluded on the basis of colour or creed. I would refer those who are interested in pursuing this matter to the very important publication by Professor Jerzy Zubrzycki, who made a study of Arthur Calwell and the origin of post‐war immigration.

The reason I feel very deeply about this is because, if one ever had a political mentor and political father, Arthur Calwell was mine. I was a pallbearer at his funeral. Three things happened at his funeral, but I will only mention the two which are relevant to this debate. Firstly, the former Prime Minister, Robert Gordon Menzies, who had lost his ability to walk, turned up outside St Patrick's Cathedral in his car. He sat there and paid tribute to his political opponent, personal friend and colleague. As the hearse passed, Robert Gordon Menzies lifted his hat, and then he left.

The other thing that occurred on that day—and I refer this to the honourable member for Oxley—is that the only community in Calwell's electorate of Melbourne which closed its shops and trade while the funeral was taking place was the Chinese community. That was because Arthur Calwell was not merely their representative, he was their friend. When he left the ministry and was in opposition, he chose to use his time by learning another language, and the language he chose to learn was Mandarin.

He laid the basis for our immigration policy. The face of Australia we see today owes a great deal to his energy, his foresight and, indeed, the hard role he had to play. He had to deal with the issue of Japanese war brides. He had to deal with complex issues in a community where there was still, as I said, pain and suffering caused by the war.
Zubrzycki said that, on 2 August 1945, the then Leader of the Opposition, Robert Menzies, pledged his party's support, choosing to underscore Calwell's statement. Menzies said:

We may have only those next 25 years in which to make the best possible use of our chance to survive. Our first requirement is additional population . . . These are grave words which I believe to be entirely true . . . My pledge to the Minister is that, if a choice has to be made between a policy of extreme caution and an adventurous policy which accepts risks because great results are involved, then let us have a more adventurous policy.
I agree with Zubrzycki's comment that, in saying this, Menzies laid down a firm foundation for Australia's bipartisan policy on immigration.

Any person applying to come to Australia comes here on the basis of facing the same uniform test. Therefore, it is a matter of concern to me—and I think to many of my parliamentary colleagues on both sides of the House—when a newly elected member, one of our number, says that one group in the community should be excluded. She says that they should not be considered as potential citizens of Australia. Why? She makes no apology for it—it is because they are Asian.

As a concept, that is a reflection upon all Australians of Chinese origin who have made a great contribution to this nation. Is she saying that if she had had a serious heart condition when Dr Chang was alive that she would not have been operated on by him because he was Asian?

In Queensland recently, there was a significant art exhibition of Asian art and culture. This reflects the fact that we are part of Asia, even though we have a European culture and European heritage. However, the one thing that all ministers for immigration know—and I said this when I was working in that capacity—is that the one thing that is certain is that the last group that gets off the boat will cop the criticism.

After the war, if they were Italian or Greek, there were some fairly fanciful names used to describe them. And as these people became part of our community, I had given to me, when I was minister for immigration, an article written in one of the Sydney tabloids. The heading was: `Australia being Latinised'. What had the Italians done? An enterprising reporter had actually been in that part of Sydney where Italian settlers had bought houses. But worse than that, they had actually opened restaurants and, worse again, the menus were in Italian. And Australia was being `Latinised'.

We have heard from the member for Oxley that Australia is being `Asianised'. It is palpable nonsense. It is ignorant nonsense. And words hurt. I have in my electorate a significant Jewish community, many of whom were victims of the Holocaust. No‐one could have foreseen the fact, and Adolf Hitler, whether we like it or not, was democratically elected. What did he do? All the economic problems that then faced the German people were blamed onto one group: the Jews. And what started as words of hatred which were picked up, led to Kristallnacht and to the persecution of that group and, ultimately, to the Holocaust and the destruction of those people.

I am not saying that is what is contemplated here, but what I am saying is that there is no place in this parliament, no matter how vigorously asserted, or how ignorant the person making the statement is, where you say that you now introduce into your immigration policy a set of standards by which people are excluded on the basis of their country of origin. Australia has moved beyond that. And the kind of allegations that are made by the honourable member for Oxley have no place in this parliament. I do not argue with her right to say them, but they are palpably wrong and immoral.

I was carrying out my parliamentary responsibilities at the IPU and on the way home from China I picked up, as did many other passengers on the plane, a major Hong Kong newspaper. What did I find on about page 3 or page 5—and I still have the cutting? There was a heading: `Racism growing in Australia'. And what was it referring to? It was a reference to racism and racist attitudes being shown towards Asian people. And who was quoted? The honourable member for Oxley was quoted. The honourable member for Oxley was featured in a paper circulating amongst the population of Hong Kong and many other parts of Asia.

That is doing the Australian people great damage because the majority of Australian people and the majority of members of this parliament do not share those views. They reject those views. And I hope that the honourable member for Oxley will give some thought to that.

There is one other matter that I feel I should raise, and I can understand the enthusiasm for the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). He is a political stayer and, as a political stayer, he fought his way through to the highest office in the land. But, equally, this view that he has that somehow his elevation to office has brought a new sense of freedom, and that political correctness—whatever that means—is no longer the order of the day, and that political correctness means that you have to support what are the prevailing views in this society, is wrong. I do not believe that this position was ever part of the Hawke or the Keating governments. And as one who has been in politics some time, I am bound to say that most of that time I would have been regarded by the governments of the day as being politically incorrect.

I started at an early age of 18 stuffing letterboxes in Richmond and Hawthorn in the anti‐communist referendum. If you did that, you were regarded as a communist at worst, and as a pro‐communist at best—a politically incorrect position. I was involved in the first of the nuclear protests and that was a very politically incorrect position.

I am bound to say that at the recent protest at Mururoa I was joined by a number of my parliamentary colleagues from the Liberal Party, and I was pleased to see that their presence has now made me politically correct. Equally, I found myself in the situation where I was opposed to the conscription of Australian youth for the war in Vietnam, and that also led to strong allegations that one was disloyal, one was not prepared to stand up to fight the threat of communism. I remember seeing pamphlets in my community saying: better stop them there than have them come here, with a big red arrow not coming out of Vietnam but actually coming out of China. That was a politically incorrect position. It was a minority position in the beginning and ultimately, of course, we were proved right.

It was the same with apartheid. I remember seeing my fellow citizens being brutally bashed in a legitimate and proper democratic protest on the occasion of the South African rugby tour game taking place in Melbourne. That was then a totally politically incorrect position, but not any more. History has caught up with us and our views have been proved right, and the evidence now being given in South Africa shows just how right it was.

So this view of political correctness depends upon how you see it. The fact is that in our political life the culture in this parliament has changed. After the Vietnam War I was a lone voice speaking on behalf of Vietnam veterans who had been exposed to herbicides. For three years I was pretty much a lone voice because the government did not want to know about it. Experiments that have taken place in America over the last five to 10 years have proved that those concerns are right and that there is a clear correlation between some of the conditions of the children of Vietnam veterans and Vietnam veterans themselves and their exposure to defoliants.

What might be seen as a politically correct position today is not necessarily a politically correct position tomorrow, and this view that somehow in this new spirit of tolerance you can say anything you like, you can characterise people on the basis of their colour or their creed, is totally unacceptable. It is even more unacceptable in this parliament. There is an old saying: if it walks like a duck, it quacks like a duck and it looks like a duck, it is probably a duck.
For those people who want to engage in this kind of political nonsense, I believe they have no real contribution to make to this parliament. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks, Noel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Like many on the coalition side, I am a person who is very pleased to be in government after 13 years, but also equally pleased to be associated with this budget, the first Howard‐Costello budget of the coalition. I know a lot of commentators have said that the budget is strong but fair, and as I go around my electorate and other electorates this has been echoed by the people that I have spoken to. Over the last 13 years they have faced the Labor Party and also faced the neglect of the former government for Australian families who they have purported to represent, who seem, particularly the middle income group, to be going further and further down, getting further and further behind. But at last they have seen some hope in this government.

SPEECH.PARA: Farmers have also been affected over the last 13 years. Certainly, they had to face droughts and low commodity prices, but the actions of the previous government did not help them. And to small business, who are really the backbone of the economy, it seemed that every time they turned around there was some more tax and more red tape. As I went around the electorate before the last election, and the one before that, small business people were saying, `We are getting older and older, we are working harder when we should be starting to take it easy, and we have a business here which is really our superannuation but no‐one in their right mind would want to buy.'

They were really feeling the brunt of the policies of the previous government. So they were delighted when the coalition was elected and more delighted when they saw the policies put forward by the government. But they are starting to get a bit edgy now because we are having some problems getting those measures through the Senate, even though we have a very large majority in the House of Representatives and, I believe, a mandate from the people to have that legislation passed.

Like so many people in the community, I am both angry and disappointed that the Labor government's legacy to this great nation has been a mountain of debt in excess of over $100 billion. It seems to me that Labor governments have this reputation of being large taxers and large spenders, and you need the tax if you are going to spend. I notice the paper put out by one of the senators which says that income in taxes and charges in 1992‐93 was $95 billion and it had increased to $124 billion in 1995‐96. That is a rise of 30.9 per cent—and all that money has been spent. If we move to loans, it was $32 billion as at 30 June 1991, it rose to $100 billion at 30 June 1996—and that is all gone. Assets sales over four years—Qantas, the Commonwealth Bank et cetera—totalled $8.68 billion. All that is gone.

The worst part of it was that infrastructure investment in the mid‐1980s was eight per cent of outlays, was down to 4.7 per cent when Mr Keating was appointed Prime Minister and this year—1995‐96—is down to minus 0.3 per cent. That is a tragedy for our nation and is really something we have to act on very quickly. Of course, it was not only the Federal government that had a problem. We saw what happened in Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia and it is starting to happen in Queensland. As I said before, it just seems that when you have Labor governments they like to spend big so they have to tax in a large way.

The interest on the debt in the 1996‐97 budget will cost more than is allocated to defence, education and industry assistance. I am also fairly upset that the coalition has had to start its first term trying to claw its way up from the bottom of a deep financial hole dug by the mismanagement of successive Hawke‐Keating governments. Faced with a budget deficit of $10.3 billion in 1995‐96, the government has had to embark on a firm fiscal strategy to eliminate the budget deficit in order to secure the financial future of the nation.

The coalition has been forced to make some tough and difficult decisions with the goodwill, understanding and cooperation of the Australian people. I must say that, despite the coalition having to take some strong actions, the Australian people—certainly the ones I have spoken to—on both sides of the political fence have said, `It is about time governments were honest with us and told us where we stood. We don't mind bearing the burden as long as we are going to get somewhere at the end of it.' That is the attitude that I have seen in many people.

The majority of people have accepted that it was imperative for the new government to take stern fiscal action. The majority of people accept that everyone has been asked to shoulder the burden. They accept the pain, knowing the government's budget strategy to reduce debt will secure a better future for all Australians and for future generations. Some of the people who have come into my office have complained about the problem they are going to face, the cutbacks in their area. I have asked them to consider the situation and said to them, `Do you want to bear some of the short term pain now for the future as an Australian, or do you want to be an Australian who just doesn't care about the future, doesn't care about obtaining work for your children and your grandchildren, the quality of life and the standard of living?'

While most people I have spoken to have not been happy about it, they have agreed that that is the way we ought to be going. All they ask of their government is honesty and they want fair play. They do not want to have one section of the community bear all the load. They want it to be spread right throughout the community. Our government would have been quite irresponsible if it had failed to take firm but fair action to turn around the Australian economy after a decade of economic vandalism. That is what it was that put us in that situation.

Failure to take this tough, unpopular fiscal decision at the correct time would have condemned the Australian people to a continuing period of rising deficit and debt into the next century—this has been said many times before, but we should keep repeating it; we have to do something and that is why we have to get our legislation through the Senate—it would have exposed them and their families to a bleak future, and applied pressure to interest rates and to jobs growth.

Despite the economic mess inherited from the Hawke‐Keating administration, the Howard government has been able to deliver in full on its key election promises. First of all, it has delivered to families, and families are the cornerstone of our great nation—we know that. We really had to do something for families, which seemed to be falling further and further behind. I do not know, Mr Deputy Speaker—and I know that you would have been aware of this as you went around your electorate—how some of those families survived. People who were earning what once was a really good wage, say, between $30,000 and $40,000 per year, with a few children, were finding that they were slipping back further and further. They were wondering what in the heck was going on and what was causing this. The Howard government has looked into this situation and is trying desperately to help these families.
Our young people who are unemployed are being trained and retrained and retrained—for what? There is no real training and no real jobs. The Howard government is trying to do something about this.

BREAK.PARA: We have mentioned small business. They just thought that they would have to keep on working until they were carried out in a pine box. There was no way they could retire because no‐one wanted their business and that is their superannuation. And, of course, there are the elderly.

I know the Labor Party finds it painful to come to grips with the fact that the first Howard government budget has been a winner, as evidenced by the strong support of the Australian people and the majority of media commentators and economists. The Labor Party's pathetic attempt to attack certain sections of the budget and to resort to a campaign of scaremongering clearly illustrates just how out of touch the Labor Party continues to be with the Australian people.

One of the key promises of the Howard government was the $1 billion family tax initiative, which is being delivered in full, restoring hope and reducing the tax burden on families with children. We have kept faith with the Australian community by keeping our promise to look after the poor and needy by maintaining and enhancing the social security safety net. The people who benefit most are those lower and middle income families with children, a group which, as I said before, was neglected by the previous government.

Single income families with several young children will benefit between $40 and $50 extra each fortnight. This will certainly relieve some of the economic pressure. There will be assistance through the taxation system, while low income families will be able to claim the family tax payment through the social security system, paid fortnightly with their family payment.

I know that members on the opposite side of the House would be concerned about what is happening to families in Australia. We have had inquiries into the Child Support Agency and family law. Much needs to be done there; I have spent a great deal of time in my office and I would say the major issues would be the Child Support Agency and family law. This is one of the problems we face in Australia and, I suppose, why our budgets blow out: family breakdown. We have to look seriously—both the government and the opposition—at this problem and see where we are going with it because I do not think we can sustain it too far into the future.

Small business, which is at the heart of rural and regional Australia, has been given a much needed economic boost in this budget. Small business, as I said before, suffered enormous economic setbacks under Labor policies, which produced record business closures and bankruptcies. I mention the rural sector because if you go to many towns—not even outback towns but regional towns—you will find the shops boarded up and closed. There are many reasons for that and we cannot blame just the economy. It is modern transport and certainly there has been tremendous pressure on those businesses in rural and regional areas.

The budget has restored incentives for small business; incentives aimed at creating an economic environment in which that important sector can confidently expand and create real jobs and get Australians back to work and be part of an exciting and innovative government program to revamp the nation's traineeship and apprenticeship schemes, which will offer significant working opportunities for young school leavers.
I have found that a number of towns in my electorate are held up because of the lack of tradesmen in the area. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Main Committee adjourned at 10.01 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 18 June 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) What measures is he undertaking to redress undue delays in the receipt of settlement monies under sections 23 and 24 of the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995 in respect of workers' compensation claims.
(2) Will the Government support legislation to resolve the delays.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) The Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995 was introduced by the previous Government without adequate consideration to the administrative burdens imposed by the legislation. For example, in New South Wales the Health Insurance Commission predicted 25000 claims in the first year. In the first three months alone almost twice that number of claims were received. To address the backlog the Health Insurance Commission has put processing staff on overtime and engaged additional (temporary) staff.

(2) Yes. Amending legislation, supported by all parties, was passed in the current session of Parliament. The amendments to the Act introduce provisions which enable an insurer to release 90 per cent of the compensation amount payable to a claimant, provided the insurer pays over to the Commonwealth the remaining 10 per cent and that the HIC receives the completed Notice of Charge.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 19 June 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) What recurrent funding did the Commonwealth allocate for the University of West Sydney in (a) 1990‐91, (b) 1991‐92, (c) 1992‐93, (d) 1993‐94, (e) 1994‐95 and (f) 1995‐96 in constant dollar terms.
(2) What recurrent funding did the previous Government foreshadow for the University for 1996‐97.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) The Commonwealth provides operating grant funding to higher education institutions in the form of a single operating grant allocated on a calendar year basis. As a result, figures have been provided for calendar years rather than financial years. Funding levels for calendar years 1990‐1996 are shown in the table below.
*Based on Budget 1995 Cost Levels
(2) The level of funding foreshadowed by the previous Government for the University of Western Sydney for 1997 is $170,030,000.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Employment Service and Youth Access Centre Services

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 20 June 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: How many clients in each postcode area are served by the Port Adelaide (a) Commonwealth Employment Service office and (b) Youth Access Centre.
How many persons are employed at the Port Adelaide (a) Commonwealth Employment Service Office and (b) Youth Access Centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The clients served by the Port Adelaide Commonwealth Employment Service and Youth Access Centre are all registered with the Port Adelaide Commonwealth Employment Service. The figures provided give the number of clients for each post code.
Staffing resources as at 1 August 1996 provided for an average staffing level of 29 in the Port Adelaide Commonwealth Employment Service and an average staffing level of 4 in the Youth Access Centre.

Four Aboriginal Education Unit Staff are also based in the Port Adelaide Youth Access Centre. These staff administer Aboriginal Education Direct Assistance programs including the Aboriginal Tutorial Assistance Scheme and the Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness program in Government and Non‐Government Schools. The Unit covers schools in the southern areas of South Australia, including the western suburbs of Adelaide down to Noarlunga and country areas including Mount Gambier and the Murraylands.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Was Australia represented at (a) the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission at the meeting in Chile in April 1996 co-organised with the Permanent Commission for the South Pacific and (b) the meeting in Washington on the Planning Committee of the Global Ocean Observing System of the World Meteorological Organisation and the UN Program in May 1996 to coordinate projects and activities between the diverse groups; if so, by whom; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a) No. The meeting in Chile was the VIII Session of the Joint Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission (IOC)/World Meteorological Organization (WMO)/Permanent South Pacific Commission (CPPS) Working Group on the Investigations of El Nino, held in Concepcion on 17 and 18 April 1996. CPPS is a southeast Pacific intergovernmental organisation. Its headquarters are in Santiago.

Dr Angus McEwan, Australia's representative on the IOC, received an invitation from the Executive Secretary of the IOC to nominate an Australian representative to attend the meeting. The invitation was received on 31 January 1996, and a reply requested no later than 15 February. Dr McEwan contacted members of Australia's oceanographic research community, but no one was able to attend due to a combination of the short notice, funding considerations, and the concentration of the meeting on matters pertaining to the southeastern Pacific.
(b) Yes. The meeting was the Second Planning Session of the IOC-WMO-UN Environment Programme (UNEP) Committee for the Global Ocean Observing System (GOOS), held in Washington on 16 and 17 May 1996.

Australia was represented at the meeting by Dr McEwan, who is Australia's delegate to, and Vice-Chairman of, the IOC-WMO-UNEP Committee for GOOS. It was also attended by Mr Ben Searle of the Australian Oceanographic Data Centre, who represented the International Oceanographic Data and Information Exchange (IODE) program and the Integrated Global Ocean Services System (IGOSS). Mr Searle is the Chairman of IODE.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Medicare Services: Electoral Division of Port Adelaide

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice on, 20 August 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: How many Medicare services were (a) provided and (b) direct billed by (i) general practitioners and (ii) specialists in each postcode area in the electoral division of Port Adelaide between 1 July 1995 and 31 May 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Based on claims processed by the Health Insurance Commission, in the 12 months to the end of June 1996 (the latest period for which data are available), 815,059 services were provided by general practitioners and 233,121 services were provided by specialists in the electoral division of Port Adelaide. Of these, 743,326 services (91.2 per cent) provided by general practitioners were direct billed and 114,478 services (49.1 per cent) provided by specialists were direct billed. Details by postcode are as follows:
Notes:
n.a.—not available for confidentiality reasons
Since the data are based on claims processed, negative values can occur due to cheque cancellations etc.

Where a postcode has overlapped electoral boundaries, Medicare data have been apportioned between Federal Electoral Divisions using the relative proportion of population for the postcode in question in each Federal Electoral Division (Source: 1991 Census of Population and Housing).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Did the previous Government increase the safety net threshold under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme from $407 to $600 with effect from 1 January 1996.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to claims that the size of the increase has caused significant concern and hardship particularly amongst pensioners.
(3) Will he re‐examine the increase with a view to linking increases to changes in the CPI.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) The previous Government did increase the safety net threshold for general patients (non card holders) from $407 to $600 with effect from 1 January 1996.
(2) The threshold applies to general patients (non cardholders), not to pensioners or other concessional patients where the threshold is 52 times the copayment (currently 52 x $2.70 = $140.40).

(3) The threshold and the copayments for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme are indexed by the Consumer Price Index. This occurs on 1 January each year. Where changes have occurred in the Budget to date from 1 January 1997, the levels will not be indexed until 1 January 1998.

Under the Migrant Resource Centre (MRC) program, Northern Metropolitan Migrant Resource Centre (Broadmeadows) operates a sub-area office, known as the Moreland Outreach Service, which is located at 536 Sydney Road, Brunswick 3046.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a letter dated 26 February 1996 from a former member for Parramatta advising constituents in Winston Hills NSW that discussions between the Federal and State Governments had led to an agreement on equal funding for the Western facing ramps from Windsor Road to the M2 motorway and that the then Minister for Transport had transferred $8.7 million in Federal road funding on one condition that the new ramps were built.

(2) Did the Federal and NSW Governments enter into the agreement referred to in part (1) if so, (a) what is the status of the agreement, (b) what are the terms of the agreement, (c) what mechanism was used to ensure that the funds would be directed to the construction of the ramps and (d) have the funds been spent.

(3) If the funds were spent, was it on a purpose other than contained in the agreement; if so, what action will the Commonwealth take to recover the funds and ensure that the terms of the agreement are met.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) I am aware of statements made by the former Member for Parramatta about ramps to the M2.
There has been no agreement between the Commonwealth and the NSW Government to fund ramps from Windsor Road to the M2.

The M2, from Seven Hills to Pennant Hills Road, forms part of the proposed new National Highway route between Liverpool and Hornsby (the so‐called Western Sydney Orbital). However, because the M2 is privately funded it has not been declared part of the National Highway System and is therefore ineligible for Federal funding. The former Government had announced, but not committed, substantial funding for the section of the Western Sydney Orbital from the M5 to the M4. There was no commitment to funding the Western Sydney Orbital north of the M4 or any additional work on the M2.
No funds have been paid by the Commonwealth to NSW for this project.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Has the Minister received advice on the impact upon businesses of the proposed requirement for unemployed persons to maintain a job seeker's diary; if so, will the Minister provide a copy of the advice.
(2) At which stages will businesses approached by job seekers be involved in the new processes.
(3) What actions will business be required to take.
(4) Has the time involved in meeting the requirements by each business been calculated; if so, what were the results.
(5) When the Minister's Department reviews a job seeker's activities recorded in the diary, will the onus of proof rest on the job seeker or the business involved.

(6) What action will be taken to assist employers who feel obliged to keep additional records to ensure that job seekers are not unfairly penalised when they are unable to prove that they approached an employer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) There is no requirement of employers to take any action with the Jobseeker Diary. The Diary is simply a record of the customer's job search which will be used by the Department to assist in determining whether a customer is satisfying the activity test. Employers will not be required to fill in entries in the Diary.
(2) In a small number of cases, the Department may contact an employer to verify that the customers did in fact contact that employer.

(3) Employers may be asked to supply information on whether they had a vacancy and whether the customer applied for that job. Business will not be required to maintain records in order to comply with requests from the Department.

(4) The Department anticipates that the amount of time employers spend dealing with requests to be minimal. Only the employer contact details of a small percentage of customers will be followed up, usually by a short phone call. The Department has recently introduced the Employer Contact Unit which provides a single point of call for employers to quickly and more easily provide information to the Department.

(5) The Diary will be accepted as being a true record of the customer's job search activity. Employers may be contacted if the Department has doubts regarding the authenticity of the job search. If the employer cannot confirm or deny the contact with the customer, the Department would, in most cases, continue to pay the customer, but may re‐issue them with a Diary.
(6) Employers may wish to discuss this matter with the Department's Employer Contact Unit which may be able to provide helpful advice.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Has the Minister received advice on the impact upon businesses of the proposed requirement for unemployed persons to maintain a job seeker's diary; if so, will the Minister provide a copy of the advice.
(2) When the Minister's Department reviews a job seeker's activities recorded in the diary, will the onus of proof rest on the job seeker or the business involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I refer Mr Crean to the answer provided to Question 565.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) With respect to the proposed requirement for unemployed persons to maintain a job seeker's diary, to what extent will regional factors be taken into account in determining the number of jobs for which a job seeker must apply each fortnight.
(2) Will individual benchmarks be set in each departmental region; if so, what are the details.
(3) How will benchmarks be applied to determine an individual's job searching requirements.
(4) What factors will be considered in determining benchmarks and what weighting will be given to each factor.
(5) Have all area consultative committees been consulted to ensure that specific conditions applying to each departmental region are taken into account when determining regional benchmarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) and (4) Benchmarks are derived from Australian Bureau of Statistics and (ABS) and Department of Employment, Education, Training and (4) Youth Affairs (DEETYA) labour force data and from the ABS business register. The benchmark is designed to reflect the state of each Department of Social Security Regional Office's local labour market.

A nominal benchmark ranging between seeking 2 and 8 jobs per fortnight was set, based upon the size of the Region's labour force. The greater the labour force, the higher the benchmark. This was then adjusted up or down depending upon the level of unemployment in the Region. Regions of low unemployment were scaled up, high unemployment Regions were scaled down. Regional Managers may adjust their benchmark up or down to take into account regional factors that may not be evident in the data used to derive the benchmark. For example, a major employer may open or close or there may be seasonal influences such as fruit picking and the like. ABS employer data was also supplied to Regional Managers to assist them in assessing the state of their local labour market.

(2) Benchmarks are developed for each Department of Social Security Regional Office. These are shown below. Regional Managers have the authority to change their benchmark, therefore, the benchmark in use by a Region may vary from that supplied.

(3) The benchmark is the starting point for calculating a customer's minimum job search requirement. The customer's job search requirement is then increased or decreased depending on their degree of labour market advantage or disadvantage.

Factors that may increase the job search requirement include year 12 or post school qualifications, work skills and recent completion of a labour market program. Factors that may reduce job search include minor disabilities, aged over 50 years, little education or no/limited access to public transport.
(5) The benchmarks were developed by the Department of Social Security using the data detailed in (1) DEETYA area consultative committees were not involved.
LABOUR MARKET BENCHMARKS
Main Second

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Prime Minister's announcement in his June 1996 "Howard Report" to the electors of Bennelong that Sydney is to be guaranteed a second international airport regardless of the outcome of the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) at Badgerys Creek.
(2) What environmental issues at the proposed Holsworthy site must the Government take account of under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.
(3) Does the Minister endorse the Prime Minister's announcement referred to in part (1).
(4) What recommendation will the Minister provide to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development if the EIS now underway recommends against both the Holsworthy and Badgerys Creek sites.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Yes.

(2) I have directed that an environmental impact statement (EIS) be prepared in relation to the proposal for a second major airport at either Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy. The Administrative Procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 specify the contents of an EIS and the procedures for determining the matters to be dealt with, and the extent to which those matters shall be dealt with, by an EIS.
Draft guidelines for the EIS were released for public comment from 22 July 1996 to 2 September 1996 and submissions received will be taken into account in preparing the final guidelines.

(3) I will ensure that the assessment conducted under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 is adequate, open and transparent. Broader questions related to aviation policy and the issue of a second airport should be directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development.
(4) It would be inappropriate for me to pre‐empt the outcomes of the environmental assessment process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 22 August 1996:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a very successful chicken meat processing industry within the electoral division of Greenway, conducted by several companies and employing many persons; if not, will he ensure that his department apprises him of the extent of this industry in the electoral division of Greenway.
(2) Is he able to say whether persons involved in the chicken meat processing industry will not be affected in any way by the opening up of imports of chicken meat into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) If the honourable member would like to provide me with briefing on the chicken meat processing industry in the electorate of Greenway I would be happy to receive it.

(2) I have gone to great lengths to consult thoroughly with the chicken meat industry in considering both the quarantine and economic impacts on the domestic industry of the proposed import of cooked chicken meat under the proposed Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) protocol.

Following discussions I held with industry in May and June this year, I established two joint Industry/Government Working Groups. The first Group considered the potential economic impact of cooked chicken meat imports as well as any transitional adjustment measures which might be considered. While recognising the difficulties of assessing the economic impact without historical data, the Working Group has estimated that imports could represent from 2% to 5% of total Australian chicken meat consumption.
The second Group is enabling industry to have technical consultation on the draft quarantine requirements published by AQIS. This Working Group is in the process of concluding its work.
All responses and industry concerns will be considered carefully by the Government prior to the finalisation of the quarantine policy process.
